comments.commentBody: @Josh Hill: Somehow the Israelis managed to establish a peaceful and mutually salutary relationship with the people of Germany.  The lunatics of Hamas have threatened to drive the Israelis into the sea but, unlike the Nazis, they have about as much chance of doing so as we citizens of New York have of ridding our city of all of its rodents. The great irony is that global trade and financing agreements depend upon US law; for finance, New York State; for governance, Delaware, and claims filed by a variety of suitors and plaintiffs end up in US courts.

Even cases tried in London and the Hague are often tried under the compelling US stature. These same corporations that use loopholes for tax avoidance, turn to US laws and courts for full protections in cases of dispute.

That's having it both ways.

But the details described point to a larger challenge: the subtle undermining of global sovereignty by scattering operations so one set of national laws apply--in fact to find locations networked together so as few laws as possible apply.

Apple is a prime example; its cash-on-hand (cash!) make it the 55th largest GNP among the world's nation-states; that's the total economic output and production of these states in all sectors.

Seen through the lens of political economy, the US offers several large loopholes, but America is simply first among equals. Whether among the states or among nations, the corporations have a global bazaar of benefits, some of which benefitted a former US Presidential candidate.

Surprisingly, many saw nothing wrong with a sovereign leader parking money overseas, following the path of dictators and tyrants who used power for greed.

The party that nominated that candidate sits in a majority in the House and will block any effort to change loopholes. It weakens the nation to empower wealth.

Why would you think that democracy as Franklin knew it came to an end on 9/11 and a new version has to be contemplated? Was it because terrorists caused very serious damage to the country?

I'm sure there were people who watched the White House burning in 1812 and thought the same thing. Or those watching the Confederates invade Pennsylvania in 1863. Or those who saw the destruction of over 300 buildings along with many deaths in the Oklahoma City terrorist bombing in 1995. Same for the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993, intended to bring down the twin towers.

9/11 was one event in a long history of violence on US soil. In addition to violence, there were such events as the FBI's secret program COINTELPRO that was intended to destroy lives and ruin reputations (found out only by the Ellsburg-like group that burgled the FBI building in Media, PA, in 1971). Surely every one of those events should have caused you to declare that democracy as we know it is over, and to call for a democracy inconceivable to Franklin. I personally do not want such a "democracy."

Eh, no, it didn't. We lost way more people fighting ourselves in the civil war. 9-11 was comparable to Pearl Harbor in casualties. Let's not lose our heads over 9-11. The terrorists had a good day; we had a bad one. The terrorists win a battle and can still lose the war. Freaking out and giving up our 4th amendment rights loses us the whole war. I'd rather be free than safe.

Some version of what the NSA is doing is very likely inevitable, one hopes with more rigorous, less mere formal judicial and congressional oversight. As I read Professor Lynch's admirable piece, finding in it nothing to disagree with, my thoughts went back to 9/11, At the moment the second airplane drove into the tower, when the buildings one after the other collapsed, beyond the agony of my helpless sympathy for the victims, the thought came to me that the enterprise of American Democracy, its extraordinary fundamentals of chance and contingency, had come to an end, and some other version of that enterprise, even if one inconceivable to Benjamin Franklin, had to be contemplated. What politician, become president, would dare risk destroying essential technological defenses against another attack on the scale of 9/11? We can preserve a formal democracy if we guard against the excesses and violations the author describes. If we fail in this, it will be due to a moral failure to comprehend that democracy in America as understood in the eighteenth century by Franklin and his associates, came to an end on September 11, 2001.

While you are right about the "territoral tax system" and the lack thereof in the U.S. is mind boggling as you pay for example the German income tax and then additionally the U.S. income tax. And the U.S. is the ONLY industrial country to tax its citizens living in another country.

But the part of the "inversion" you sadly didn't get quite right as it gives corporations the possibility to pay no taxes in the U.S. or other higher-tax countries at all, as companies like Google, Apple etc. clearly demonstrate.
How they do it is simple, they "move" all earnings from the U.S. to another low tax country. They do it, for example, by selling their patents and other intellectual properties to their subsidies for 1$ and pay in return high license fees to their subsidies for each object they sell in the U.S. or Europe. Or they pay absurd fees for simple items, like a pencil for 10$ to their foreign subsidy to make no revenue on sells in the U.S. and all money flows to their "office-only" subsidy on the Cayman-Islands. It is really no mystery how this works and is perfectly legal. But it robs the countries from the needed income to maintain their roads, police, courts or whatever you need to provide a stable business friendly culture.
This got a real big issue over here in Germany and Europe in general, as giants like Google, Apple or IKEA excel at that technique and they officially generate no taxable income, even be provided with all the infrastructure they need to make business.

Those who invest in "inversions" are international capitalists who do not give a thought to the economic, social or political survival of America or its citizens.

I will not invest in them.

But "The Rich" will! That's why they are rich!

The rush to eliminate taxes as a way of shrinking government to nothing is a psychopathy that can only be explained by mass mental angst and mass corruption feed off that angst. Grover Norquist obviously has built a nice cottage industry for himself leaching off the movement.  One question: who will he call for protection in the middle of the night, his local GOP precinct captain?!  A larger, more disturbing question: Why is he so persuasive?  Is there honesty in responding positively to that persuasion? I think not.

There are also historians like Avi Shlaim, Zeev Sternhell and Ilan Pappe. This conflict is a political one not an ethnic one. Edward Said was a friend of Barenboim and an admirer of Freud. There are people of peace among Palestinians, Israelis, Americans and Europeans. And yes I totally agree that neocons should be aware of all of them.

I see not compassion nor common sense. America has yet to confront and atone for the atrocities committed on the slaves and Native Americans. And yet the Palestinians have it far worse. This sentence; "As long as the suffocation felt in Gaza is not alleviated, we in Israel will not be able to breathe freely either." demonstrates a perspective concerned only with itself. Steal their families farms and homes of generations past, imprison them on reservations that you continue to encroach upon, control their water, electricity, agriculture, sanitation, trade and travel; and when they refuse to go quietly into their oppressive night, when they try to fight with fireworks, then slaughter their children, sisters, brothers, mothers and fathers, and lament to the world how they dare challenge your Right to Exist.

War criminals? I guess you should first look to our US leaders for what has been done in Afghanistan and Iraq at a far greater cost to human life.

Unless you have had someone close to you either hurt or killed in the Boston Marathon bombings, 9-11, or the endless attacks on Israel, you likely will never have the compassion or understanding for what it means to be the victim of the hate and terror that Hamas seeks to inflict on civilians in their quest for a world of Islam.

Don't think for a minute Stu that your compassion for Palestinians will stop these terrorists from wanting to kill you or your loved ones.

In a Youtube video, I heard Milton Friedman say that he preferred small government because, the smaller the government the smaller the influence of those who influence the government. He may have been right. We have a strong political class in this country, guaranteed re-election every term, who do not represent the will of the people, but the will of those who supply the money to continue this feudal system. This can go on for a very long time, and there are no limits to the destructive indifference that is currently the norm. We do not deal with any problems; immigration, taxation, infrastructure and poverty. Despite a flat line approval rating it goes on and on and on. I suppose one day we will reach the breaking point. Let's hope for a better day.

Richard, you ignore substantial -- and, to my mind, definitive-- Supreme Court precedent dating back to the early 1800s that distinguishes between actual personhood and corporate personhood, the latter being restricted to property rights. See, for example, Justice Stevens's masterful dissent in Citizens United and Justice Ginsburg's masterful dissent in Hobby Lobby.

But if we are (incorrectly) conferring personhood on corporations, perhaps those rights in the U.S. should be restricted to those corporations whose ownership is domiciled here. After all, foreigners should not be able to contribute to U.S. political campaigns, and perhaps government purchasing and subsidies should be focused on domestically domiciled companies.

If we are going to (incorrectly) enshrine corporate personhood, let's follow the argument to its appropriate conclusions.

Congressman John Delaney of Maryland and Senators Bennett and Blunt have proposed legislation that would allow repatriation of overseas corporate profits at a 10% tax rate if a portion of the proceeds were used to finance a U.S. infrastructure bank.  The legislation is called the Partnership to Build America Act, is bipartisan, and is worthy of a close look.

The convenience and speed with which one can vary visual choices when using a digital screen compared to printing, mounting and hanging photos will be appealing to anyone who cares about photography and all the other visual modes we have access to. And the cost of each image should be dramatically less. As a landscape photographer I have been waiting for this for a long, long time. I am eager to sell my images to people who want to display them on a screen, the larger the better. Of course, the larger the screen -- and you obviously need a large screen if you like large images and have the wall space or even ceiling space -- the more costly the device. Just how extreme or affordable that cost will become remains to be seen. Furthermore, the energy required to run a large screen -- e.g. 30 x 45 inches or more will be costly, at least for awhile.

All American taxpayers should be infuriated at the "inversion" scam. It is not only tax evasion--25% of all U.S. corporations pay zero taxes anyway--it is a slap in the face for all Americans. These corporations use the physical and financial infrastructure of this country to make their profits and then they use a trick to repatriate those profits to Europe or the Caribbean to avoid taxes leaving wage earners to subsidize their operations. How long could they continue if the infrastructure disappeared.

Oh, but Republicans are already destroying the infrastructure. When the nation falls apart we will have them and the cheating corporations they support to thank.

Yes, Krugman is right.

But we might consider allowing corporations to deduct more than the full cost of each employee. We could let them deduct 120 percent or 150 percent of the cost of each employee (earning less than $250,000 per year) --- whatever would get them to hire more people.

The current corporate tax needs to be replaced by a tax on US earnings. Where sales occur in more than one country, then the tax should be prorated based upon the portion of sales that is in US, no matter the "home" of the corporation.

Anyone who believes that Capitalism can flourish without government regulation, especially in the face of galloping automation, is a fool. We have had enough panics, recessions and depressions to put that to rest. It is not a zero-sum game -- all levels win with proper regulation. Without it, all will lose.
